summary: Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disease of the airways characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchospasm. It is a common condition that affects people of all ages and can be managed with proper treatment.
pathophysiology: Asthma is characterized by chronic inflammation of the airways, which leads to airway hyperresponsiveness, mucus production, and airway remodeling. This results in narrowing of the airways, making it difficult to breathe. The inflammation is typically driven by a combination of genetic and environmental factors.

epidemiology.prevalence: Asthma affects approximately 300 million people worldwide.
epidemiology.incidence: The incidence of asthma is higher in children and young adults.
risk_factors: Family history of asthma or allergies
Exposure to allergens (e.g., dust mites, pollen, pet dander)
epidemiology.demographics: Asthma is more common in children and young adults, and it affects both males and females.

symptoms: Coughing (often worse at night or early morning)
signs: Use of accessory muscles for breathing
clinical_presentation.onset: Symptoms can be intermittent or persistent, often triggered by allergens, exercise, or respiratory infections.
clinical_presentation.severity_spectrum: Symptoms can range from mild to severe, with severe cases leading to asthma attacks that require immediate medical attention.

imaging_studies: Chest X-ray (to rule out other conditions)

pharmacological: Long-acting beta-agonists (LABAs) in combination with ICS

complications: Side effects from long-term medication use

prognosis.overall_prognosis: Most people with asthma can lead normal lives with proper management.
prognosis.survival_rates: With proper management, asthma does not typically affect life expectancy.
prognosis.chronic_considerations: Chronic asthma can lead to airway remodeling and persistent symptoms if not well-managed.

key_considerations: Regular monitoring and adjustment of treatment
Emergency action plan for asthma attacks
references: World Health Organization (WHO) reports on asthma
